title: David's Trials and Absalom's Rebellion
shortSummary: This chapter depicts King David's difficult journey during Absalom's rebellion, highlighting the betrayal, curses, and political intrigue he faces. It reveals David's humility and trust in God's sovereignty amid personal attacks and the strategic counsel given to Absalom.
timeline: c. 1000 BC - The reign of King David and Absalom's rebellion

keyCharacters.name: David
keyCharacters.description: The anointed king of Israel who is fleeing from his son Absalom's rebellion, demonstrating patience and reliance on God despite adversity.

keyCharacters.name: Ziba
keyCharacters.description: Servant of Mephibosheth who brings provisions to David but reports that Mephibosheth stays in Jerusalem, claiming his own loyalty to the king.

keyCharacters.name: Shimei
keyCharacters.description: A man from Saul's family who curses David and throws stones at him, accusing him of bloodshed and divine judgment.

keyCharacters.name: Absalom
keyCharacters.description: David's son who has rebelled against him, taking control of Jerusalem and seeking to solidify his power.

keyCharacters.name: Ahithophel
keyCharacters.description: A trusted counselor of David who defects to Absalom and gives shrewd advice to strengthen Absalom's rebellion.

definitions.definition: A Hebrew term meaning 'worthless' or 'wicked one,' often used to describe a person of great wickedness or lawlessness.
The royal family lineage of King Saul, Israel's first king, from whom Absalom and Shimei claim heritage.
Women who lived with a man as secondary wives, often to secure alliances or demonstrate power, as seen in Absalom’s public act.
A divine communication or authoritative counsel believed to come directly from God, indicating the high regard for Ahithophel’s advice.

outline.heading: Ziba's Provision and Report
outline.description: Ziba meets David with supplies and claims Mephibosheth has betrayed the king by staying in Jerusalem, leading David to grant Ziba all of Mephibosheth’s property. This section shows the complexities of loyalty during the rebellion.

outline.heading: Shimei's Curse and David's Restraint
outline.description: Shimei, from Saul’s family, curses David and throws stones, accusing him of bloodshed. David forbids his men from retaliating, trusting God's sovereignty and judgment, demonstrating humility and patience under trial.

outline.heading: Absalom's Arrival and Hushai's Loyalty
outline.description: Absalom enters Jerusalem with his followers and receives Hushai, David’s friend, who pretends loyalty to Absalom to serve as a spy. This highlights the political intrigue and divided loyalties in the kingdom.

outline.heading: Ahithophel's Counsel to Absalom
outline.description: Ahithophel advises Absalom to publicly dishonor David by sleeping with his concubines, a move to assert dominance and weaken David’s reputation. The chapter closes by affirming Ahithophel’s counsel was regarded as divinely inspired.

application: Trust God’s sovereignty in times of personal attack and injustice, following David’s example of restraint and faith.
Be cautious in accepting reports or accusations; seek God’s wisdom before making judgments about others’ loyalty or character.
Remain faithful and humble even when facing betrayal or opposition, knowing God can turn affliction into blessing.
Recognize the importance of godly counsel and discernment in leadership decisions, avoiding ungodly advice.

keyVerses.text: And the king said, What have I to do with you, ye sons of Zeruiah? so let him curse, because the LORD hath said unto him, Curse David. Who shall then say, Wherefore hast thou done so?
keyVerses.significance: This verse reveals David’s submission to God’s sovereign will, accepting even curses as part of God's plan.

keyVerses.text: It may be that the LORD will look on mine affliction, and that the LORD will requite me good for his cursing this day.
keyVerses.significance: David expresses hope that God will reward his patience and suffering, encouraging believers to trust in God’s justice.

keyVerses.text: And the counsel of Ahithophel, which he counselled in those days, was as if a man had enquired at the oracle of God: so was all the counsel of Ahithophel both with David and with Absalom.
keyVerses.significance: This highlights the high regard for Ahithophel’s wisdom and the danger of ungodly counsel, reminding believers to seek God’s guidance.
